Title: Chicago, North Shore & Milwaukee Railway Co.
Descriptive Text: This commuter rail line originated when a short street railway between North Chicago and Waukegan was finished in 1892. In 1908, the line extended to Milwaukee; 11 years later, when it was owned by local utilities titan Samuel Insull, it obtained access to downtown Chicago. The road's “Electroliner” train, introduced in 1941, was a popular innovation. By the latter part of the 1940s, annual revenues were about $10 million. By 1963, the road had ceased to operate.
Bibliography: This entry is part of the Encyclopedia's Dictionary of Leading Chicago Businesses (1820-2000) that was prepared by Mark R. Wilson, with additional contributions from Stephen R. Porter and Janice L. Reiff.
